channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Group Says Haitian Garment Workers Are Shortchanged on Pay
item.description: The Worker Rights Consortium reported the “theft” of part of the income legally due to the workers.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:description: Workers in a garment shop in Haiti. Production quotas and overtime figure in a report that says such employees are underpaid.

item.title: At 28, Writer Is Youngest To Receive Booker Prize
item.description: The Booker is Britain’s most prestigious literary prize, awarded annually to a novelist from Britain, Ireland or a Commonwealth country.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE BOSMAN
item.media:description: Eleanor Catton on Tuesday in London was awarded the Man Booker Prize for her novel "The Luminaries."

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,271 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Listening Post: China Rails at U.S., Seeing Its Own Money at Risk
item.description: A commentary from an official news agency calls for a “de-Americanized world” as Chinese officials worry about more than a trillion dollars in American public debt their country holds.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: The Cancer Divide: Uganda Fights Stigma and Poverty to Take on Breast Cancer
item.description: Women in Africa face long delays in treatment, a problem that Uganda is hoping to confront with a new hospital and clinic.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jessy Acen, 30, who has advanced breast cancer, is bathed by her twin sister at home in the city of Gulu, in northern Uganda. Ms. Acen, a tailor, has two young sons.

item.title: Mexico Takes Bloomberg-Like Swing at Soaring Obesity
item.description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s foundation has joined the fight against obesity in Mexico, where President Enrique Peña Nieto wants to tax sugary drinks.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A balloon seller at a market in a Mexico City neighborhood, where people come to eat traditional food and most of the time, drink Coke.

item.title: Mother of American Imprisoned in North Korea Leaves Without Him
item.description: The mother of Kenneth Bae, who has been incarcerated for nearly a year, expressed thanks to the North Korean government for letting her see her son.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Europeans Are Faulted Over Using Funds to Support Like-Minded Voices
item.description: Critics say the European Union’s practice of funding policy groups that tend to be supportive rather than critical limits discussion and fuels disenchantment over the push for greater integration.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Blasts Kill 2 And Injure An American In Myanmar
item.description: Since Friday, nine explosions have hit hotels, a Buddhist pagoda, and restaurants in Yangon and two regions north and northeast of the city.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Police officers guard a Buddhist pagoda in Yangon on Tuesday.

item.title: Rich Americans Snap Up Irish Castles for Love and Discounts
item.description: Many with deep pockets and traceable Irish roots pay cash to buy castles and manor houses at bargain rates.
item.dc:creator: By KERRY HANNON
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times

item.title: Terror Suspect Caught in Libya Appears in Manhattan Court
item.description: Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai is accused of playing a role in 1998 bombings at American Embassies that killed 224 people.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s Foreign Minister Invokes 9/11 Attack to Argue for Collective Security
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, told NBC News that one lesson of the Sept. 11 attack was “That an island of security in an unsecure world is impossible.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Second Medal of Honor For 2009 Afghan Battle
item.description: William Swenson, a former Army captain who received the medal, has been outspoken in his criticism of his superiors who failed to send in help after an ambush in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama presented the Medal of Honor to a former Army captain, William Swenson, at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Down a Road Less Traveled, Looking for the Still Heart of Russia
item.description: Inspired by a book written in 1790, a photographer set out to capture the vast differences between Russia’s cities and its hinterlands.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Britain Makes an Overture to Repair Ties With China
item.description: The country is hoping not to miss out on economic opportunities in China, which other European nations are courting.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: The Impasse Over Liability Clause in Indo-U.S. Nuclear Deal
item.description: The two nations have been unable to conclude talks on civilian nuclear energy because American companies have refused to accept the liability framework that the Indian government set in place in 2010 to deal with nuclear accidents.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By M.V. RAMANA and SUVRAT RAJU
item.media:description: Manmohan Singh, left, prime minister of India with Barack Obama, president of the United States, at the White House in Washington D.C. on Sept. 26.

item.title: Iran Presents Nuclear Plan To Big Powers
item.description: Speaking in English and using PowerPoint, the Iranian foreign minister outlined a proposal to the big powers aimed at ending the nuclear dispute.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A woman looks at a sculpture of a naked man, which was covered by a curtain at the entrance to the meeting hall at the United Nations in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: October 15
item.description: Several areas in Odisha were inundated by heavy rains in the aftermath of Cyclone Phailin.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An aerial view of the flooded areas in Balasore district of Odisha in the aftermath of Cyclone Phailin.

item.title: The Lede: Rampage in Moscow Unfolds on Camera
item.description: Video from Russian news sites and social networks showed rioting by Russian nationalists who chanted “White Power!” and “Russians Advance!” as they stormed a vegetable market in search of migrants in a working-class district.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Major Earthquake Strikes Central Philippines
item.description: The powerful quake, which killed dozens, damaged major buildings in Cebu City, a heavily populated commercial center.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Patients and family members outside a hospital following an aftershock on Tuesday in Cebu City, Philippines.

item.title: Introducing The International New York Times
item.description: The move changes the name of The International Herald Tribune and strengthens The New York Times’ 24-hour, global digital newsroom. This week, The Times is offering free access to our readers on the Web and iOS mobile apps.

item.title: Letters: Myth of the Sisterhood
item.description: A new book argues that a slice of well-educated women are moving away from the rest.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD | THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letters: A New Image of Female Authenticity
item.description: A war of resistance has broken out as women clamor for a freedom long cherished by men: the right to be physically imperfect.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Embracing the Perceived Freedom of R.V.’s
item.description: Recreational vehicles might have middle-brow associations in the United States, but in China they are seen as an upholstered magic carpet, toilet included, that provides an escape.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Israel Warns Against Partial Agreement With Iran
item.description: Israel said on Tuesday that it would “embrace a genuine diplomatic solution” to dismantle Iran’s nuclear weapons program, but urged world powers not to ease sanctions prematurely.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
